articles.headline: Health Plan Penalty Ends at Penn State
articles.snippet: The university had proposed a $100 monthly penalty for employees who failed to provide personal data in a wellness questionnaire.
articles.abstract: The university had proposed a $100 monthly penalty for employees who failed to provide personal data in a wellness questionnaire.
articles.lead_paragraph: After weeks of vociferous objections by faculty members, Pennsylvania State University said on Wednesday it was suspending part of a new employee wellness program that some professors had criticized as coercive and financially punitive.

articles.headline: In Surprise, Fed Decides to Maintain Pace of Stimulus
articles.snippet: In a reversal that stunned economists and investors, the Federal Reserve said it would continue to buy bonds to encourage growth, at least for another month and quite possibly into next year.
articles.abstract: In a reversal that stunned economists and investors, the Federal Reserve said it would continue to buy bonds to encourage growth, at least for another month and quite possibly into next year.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It turns out that the Federal Reserve is not quite ready to let go of its extra efforts to help the economy grow.

articles.headline: S.E.C. Proposes Greater Disclosure on Pay for C.E.O.’s
articles.snippet: The regulator is nearing adoption of a rule that would require chief executives to compare their pay to the median paid to employees.
articles.abstract: The regulator is nearing adoption of a rule that would require chief executives to compare their pay to the median paid to employees.
articles.lead_paragraph: The gap in pay between chief executives and rank-and-file employees has been growing steadily, and now regulators want companies to tell investors just how wide it is.

articles.headline: America’s Sinking Middle Class
articles.snippet: The standard of living of most Americans has fallen in the last 25 years; last year, the typical household made $51,017, roughly the same as in 1988.
articles.abstract: The standard of living of most Americans has fallen in the last 25 years; last year, the typical household made $51,017, roughly the same as in 1988.
articles.lead_paragraph: In some respects, 1988 has the feel of an alien, distant era. There was no such thing as the World Wide Web then. The Soviet Union was still around; the Berlin Wall still standing. Americans elected a Republican president who would raise taxes to help tame the budget deficit.

articles.headline: After Fed’s Announcement, Confusion and Relief on Wall Street
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve’s apparent change of heart left investors wondering how they got it so wrong, with several pointing an accusing finger at Ben S. Bernanke, the chairman.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve’s apparent change of heart left investors wondering how they got it so wrong, with several pointing an accusing finger at Ben S. Bernanke, the chairman.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ben S. Bernanke and the markets are having a hard time understanding each other.

articles.headline: Iran’s Leaders Signal Effort at New Thaw
articles.snippet: President Hassan Rouhani capped a series of gestures from Iran’s ruling establishment by saying the country would never “seek weapons of mass destruction, including nuclear weapons.”
articles.abstract: President Hassan Rouhani capped a series of gestures from Iran’s ruling establishment by saying the country would never “seek weapons of mass destruction, including nuclear weapons.”
articles.lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — A series of good-will gestures and hints of new diplomatic flexibility from Iran’s ruling establishment was capped on Wednesday by the highest-level statement yet that the country’s new leaders are pushing for a compromise in negotiations over their disputed nuclear program.

articles.headline: Threatening Letters Sent to 140 MF Global Vendors
articles.snippet: James W. Giddens, the court-appointed trustee liquidating the bankrupt firm, told vendors they had until Friday to defend payment they had received.
articles.abstract: James W. Giddens, the court-appointed trustee liquidating the bankrupt firm, told vendors they had until Friday to defend payment they had received.
articles.lead_paragraph: When MF Global collapsed in 2011, Lorie Meg Karlin’s brokerage company nearly disappeared along with it.

articles.headline: Sectarian Violence Reignites in an Iraqi Town
articles.snippet: Villagers in Diyala Province saw much death during the worst of Iraq’s carnage over the past decade, but they say what is happening now is far worse.
articles.abstract: Villagers in Diyala Province saw much death during the worst of Iraq’s carnage over the past decade, but they say what is happening now is far worse.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUQDADIYA, Iraq — The orange archway at the entrance to this farming community welcomes visitors in “peace.” The lush palm groves are heavy with ripe dates. For generations, Shiite and Sunni families worked the land, earning a living from their sheep and cows, their wheat fields and lemon trees.

articles.headline: Mental Health Again an Issue in Gun Debate
articles.snippet: Efforts to improve the country’s fraying mental health system to help prevent mass shootings have stalled on Capitol Hill, tied up in the broader fight on gun control.
articles.abstract: Efforts to improve the country’s fraying mental health system to help prevent mass shootings have stalled on Capitol Hill, tied up in the broader fight on gun control.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Despite deep divisions that have kept Congress from passing new gun safety laws for almost two decades, there is one aspect of gun control on which many Democrats, Republicans and even the National Rifle Association agree: the need to give mental health providers better resources to treat dangerous people and prevent them from buying weapons.
articles.byline: By Jeremy W. Peters and Michael Luo

articles.headline: Professor Says He Has Solved a Mystery Over a Slave’s Novel
articles.snippet: A novel praised for its dramatic depiction of Southern life in the mid-1850s became a best seller, but its tantalizing secret — the author’s identity — may have been solved.
articles.abstract: A novel praised for its dramatic depiction of Southern life in the mid-1850s became a best seller, but its tantalizing secret — the author’s identity — may have been solved.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2002, a novel thought to be the first written by an African-American woman became a best seller, praised for its dramatic depiction of Southern life in the mid-1850s through the observant eyes of a refined and literate house servant.

articles.headline: As Inquiries Persist, JPMorgan Loses Favor
articles.snippet: In just 18 months, JPMorgan has swung from Washington’s favorite bank to a financial punching bag.
articles.abstract: In just 18 months, JPMorgan has swung from Washington’s favorite bank to a financial punching bag.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:08 p.m. | High above Park Avenue, in a 50th-floor conference room overlooking Central Park, JPMorgan’s board members had a pressing question about regulatory problems that have dogged the bank for more than a year: are we done yet?
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Ben Protess

articles.headline: Pope Says Church Is ‘Obsessed’ With Gays, Abortion and Birth Control
articles.snippet: Saying that the Roman Catholic Church should seek a “new balance,” Pope Francis articulated his vision of an inclusive church, evoking gratitude and hope from liberal Catholics who had felt left out in the cold.
articles.abstract: Saying that the Roman Catholic Church should seek a “new balance,” Pope Francis articulated his vision of an inclusive church, evoking gratitude and hope from liberal Catholics who had felt left out in the cold.
articles.lead_paragraph: Six months into his papacy, Pope Francis sent shock waves through the Roman Catholic church on Thursday with the publication of his remarks that the church had grown “obsessed” with abortion, gay marriage and contraception, and that he had chosen not to talk about those issues despite recriminations from critics.
